'''Warrior's Challenges''' are mini-game challenges in [[Natlan]]. 

They can be played by speaking to Master Trainers in the overworld. Each tribe has three Master Trainers, and each challenge revolves around using the skills of the tribe's [[Saurian]].

==Rewards==
There are five possible scoring tiers: C, B, A, S, and SS.
* B tier rewards a [[Common Chest]]
* A tier rewards an [[Exquisite Chest]]
* S tier rewards a [[Precious Chest]]

==Trivia==
*All Master Trainers are named after words related to plants or food.
**[[Lirio]] and [[Manzana]] come from Spanish, where "[https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lirio#Spanish lirio]" means "lily or iris" and "[https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/manzana#Spanish manzana]" means "apple."
**[[Centaca]] comes from "[https://nahuatl.wired-humanities.org/content/centacatl centacatl]," meaning "a bunch or clump of herbs, thistles, lettuce, or cabbage."
**The first part of [[Quiltec]]'s name comes from "[https://nahuatl.wired-humanities.org/content/quilitl quilitl]," which in modern Spanish is referred to as "[https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quelite quelite]" (''Amaranthaceae'' or ''Coriandrum'').
**[[Xiuhyo]] is explained in [https://nahuatl.wired-humanities.org/content/xiuhyo dictionaries] as meaning "grassy" or "leaf."
**[[Cima]] comes from "[https://aztecglyphs.wired-humanities.org/content/cima-mh520r cimatl]," which could refer to the root of wild potatoes.
**[[Matzatli]] comes from "[https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/matzahtli matzahtli]," meaning pineapple.
**"[[Tepache]]" is derived from "[https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/tepache tepiatl]."
**[[Avuia]] may from [https://nahuatl.wired-humanities.org/content/ahhui%C4%81c ahhuiāc] means "tasty" or "smelling good."
